content: Again, a non-news story. This was a coincidence as the Russians wouldn't give a fat rat's a$$ about Obama's visit nor would they be worried about some vintage F-18s flying with 3 tanks onboard each to even make that far of intercept of an ancient pair of bombers that could have unloaded all their cruise missiles before the F-18s ever made it into missile range. If Russia would have had serious intentions they would have sent stealth aircraft that would remain undetected until its too late. Russia sent 2 bombers deep into Canadian airspace in 2006 without being detected which still has the canuks scratching their heads.
reply: Again, a non-news story. This was a coincidence as the Russians wouldn't give a fat rat's a$$ about Obama's visit nor would they be worried about some vintage F-18s flying with 3 tanks onboard each to even make that far of intercept of an ancient pair of bombers that could have unloaded all their cruise missiles before the F-18s ever made it into missile range. If Russia would have had serious intentions they would have sent stealth aircraft that would remain undetected until its too late. Russia sent 2 bombers deep into Canadian airspace in 2006 without being detected which still has the canuks scratching their heads. Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Without hard evidence, it all sounds like a bunch of hot air, and having seen how Putin acts on the world stage, if Russia had an actual stealth aircraft, Putin's pride wouldn't have let him keep it secret - the thing would have been the pride and joy of the MAKS airshow for the world to see.

Without hard evidence, it all sounds like a bunch of hot air, and having seen how Putin acts on the world stage, if Russia had an actual stealth aircraft, Putin's pride wouldn't have let him keep it secret - the thing would have been the pride and joy of the MAKS airshow for the world to see.

title: Canadian F18 fighters intercepted Russian bombers over Arctic on eve of Obama visit

content: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: According to sources, and unlike Obama's visit, this in not a unique event. Since Bushco decided it needed ABMs in Eastern Europe, Putin decided he needed that 'cold war' strike capability back. So the Bears have been wandering all over the place, Canada's side of the Arctic not exempted. Arctic sovereignity is still in question with all stakeholders, including Russia, stretching their 'envelopes' before negotiations begin. To this point, American claims would have far greater negative impact on Canada than anything the Russians want. That the CF-18's left a base in Alberta and managed to intercept two Bears over the ocean northwest of Tuktoyaktuk says that they were 'hustling' to get there on extra tanks, and that the Bears were moving high and slow. It's good that the radar works that well. Low and fast? It's good, as well, that they're not into taking pictures. They might have been first spotted over that airbase. Which came first, the chicken or the egg?... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
quote: Originally posted by popsiq: According to sources, and unlike Obama's visit, this in not a unique event. Since Bushco decided it needed ABMs in Eastern Europe, Putin decided he needed that 'cold war' strike capability back. So the Bears have been wandering all over the place, Canada's side of the Arctic not exempted. Arctic sovereignity is still in question with all stakeholders, including Russia, stretching their 'envelopes' before negotiations begin. To this point, American claims would have far greater negative impact on Canada than anything the Russians want. That the CF-18's left a base in Alberta and managed to intercept two Bears over the ocean northwest of Tuktoyaktuk says that they were 'hustling' to get there on extra tanks, and that the Bears were moving high and slow. It's good that the radar works that well. Low and fast? It's good, as well, that they're not into taking pictures. They might have been first spotted over that airbase.
reply: Which came first, the chicken or the egg?... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: Originally posted by Knele: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Couple of prototypes were built, but officially none are in service…….. +http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/row/mfi.htm BTW; IMHO one of the ugliest aircraft Russians have ever built! How they went from the Mig-29 & Su-27 designs to this, is mindboggling! The MFI/MiG-1.42 is anything but stealthy - it might have a reduced radar cross section, but even then it's nowhere near on par with it's European competition such as the Typhoon or Rafale. The closest I've seen to what might be a stealthy Russian fighter is the Su-47 Berkut.

reply: The MFI/MiG-1.42 is anything but stealthy - it might have a reduced radar cross section, but even then it's nowhere near on par with it's European competition such as the Typhoon or Rafale. The closest I've seen to what might be a stealthy Russian fighter is the Su-47 Berkut.

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: quote: Originally posted by Knele: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Couple of prototypes were built, but officially none are in service…….. +http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/row/mfi.htm BTW; IMHO one of the ugliest aircraft Russians have ever built! How they went from the Mig-29 & Su-27 designs to this, is mindboggling! The MFI/MiG-1.42 is anything but stealthy - it might have a reduced radar cross section, but even then it's nowhere near on par with it's European competition such as the Typhoon or Rafale. Russian stealth tech is not based on the design & RAM but rather Plasma technology. If it works like they say it does, shape & size of the airplane is irrelevant. Despite the apparent technical difficulty of designing a plasma stealth device for combat aircraft, there are claims that a system was offered for export by Russia in 1999. In January 1999, the Russian ITAR-TASS news agency published an interview with Doctor Anatoliy Koroteyev, the director of the Keldysh Research Center (FKA Scientific Research Institute for Thermal Processes), who talked about the plasma stealth device developed by his organization. The claim was particularly interesting in light of the solid scientific reputation of Dr. Koroteyev and the Institute for Thermal Processes, which is one of the top scientific research organizations in the world in the field of fundamental physics. [see "Russian scientists created revolutionary technologies for reducing radar visibility of aircraft", by Nikolay Novichkov, ITAR-TASS, January 20, 1999]. The Journal of Electronic Defense reported that "plasma-cloud-generation technology for stealth applications" developed in Russia reduces an aircraft's RCS by a factor of 100. According to this June 2002 article, the Russian plasma stealth device has been tested aboard a Sukhoi Su-27IB fighter-bomber. The Journal also reported that similar research into applications of plasma for RCS reduction is being carried out by Accurate Automation Corporation (Chattanooga, Tennessee) and Old Dominion University (Norfolk, Virginia) in the U.S.; and by Dassault Aviation (Saint-Cloud, France) and Thales (Paris, France). ["Russia Working on Stealth Plasma", by Michal Fiszer and Jerzy Gruszczynski, Journal of Electronic Defense, June 2002]. +http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plasma_stealth +http://www.military-heat.com/43/russian-plasma-stealth-fighters/
quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: quote: Originally posted by Knele: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Couple of prototypes were built, but officially none are in service…….. +http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/row/mfi.htm BTW; IMHO one of the ugliest aircraft Russians have ever built! How they went from the Mig-29 & Su-27 designs to this, is mindboggling! The MFI/MiG-1.42 is anything but stealthy - it might have a reduced radar cross section, but even then it's nowhere near on par with it's European competition such as the Typhoon or Rafale.
reply: Russian stealth tech is not based on the design & RAM but rather Plasma technology. If it works like they say it does, shape & size of the airplane is irrelevant. Despite the apparent technical difficulty of designing a plasma stealth device for combat aircraft, there are claims that a system was offered for export by Russia in 1999. In January 1999, the Russian ITAR-TASS news agency published an interview with Doctor Anatoliy Koroteyev, the director of the Keldysh Research Center (FKA Scientific Research Institute for Thermal Processes), who talked about the plasma stealth device developed by his organization. The claim was particularly interesting in light of the solid scientific reputation of Dr. Koroteyev and the Institute for Thermal Processes, which is one of the top scientific research organizations in the world in the field of fundamental physics. [see "Russian scientists created revolutionary technologies for reducing radar visibility of aircraft", by Nikolay Novichkov, ITAR-TASS, January 20, 1999]. The Journal of Electronic Defense reported that "plasma-cloud-generation technology for stealth applications" developed in Russia reduces an aircraft's RCS by a factor of 100. According to this June 2002 article, the Russian plasma stealth device has been tested aboard a Sukhoi Su-27IB fighter-bomber. The Journal also reported that similar research into applications of plasma for RCS reduction is being carried out by Accurate Automation Corporation (Chattanooga, Tennessee) and Old Dominion University (Norfolk, Virginia) in the U.S.; and by Dassault Aviation (Saint-Cloud, France) and Thales (Paris, France). ["Russia Working on Stealth Plasma", by Michal Fiszer and Jerzy Gruszczynski, Journal of Electronic Defense, June 2002]. +http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plasma_stealth +http://www.military-heat.com/43/russian-plasma-stealth-fighters/

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: quote: Originally posted by FlankerFlyer: Again, a non-news story. This was a coincidence as the Russians wouldn't give a fat rat's a$$ about Obama's visit nor would they be worried about some vintage F-18s flying with 3 tanks onboard each to even make that far of intercept of an ancient pair of bombers that could have unloaded all their cruise missiles before the F-18s ever made it into missile range. If Russia would have had serious intentions they would have sent stealth aircraft that would remain undetected until its too late. Russia sent 2 bombers deep into Canadian airspace in 2006 without being detected which still has the canuks scratching their heads. Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Without hard evidence, it all sounds like a bunch of hot air, and having seen how Putin acts on the world stage, if Russia had an actual stealth aircraft, Putin's pride wouldn't have let him keep it secret - the thing would have been the pride and joy of the MAKS airshow for the world to see. The two aircraft the Russians used were probably Tu-160's. Wiki reports that the "Bears" tracked in this incident were actually Blackjacks. Two of which penetrated US air space undetected last year, causing an investigation. The Russians have re-started the Blackjack program to pad out their fleet. If it is true that CF-18's caught them over the ocean either they're not as radar deflective or fast as the Russians think. Or maybe they were on their way home.

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: quote: Originally posted by Knele: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Couple of prototypes were built, but officially none are in service…….. +http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/row/mfi.htm BTW; IMHO one of the ugliest aircraft Russians have ever built! How they went from the Mig-29 & Su-27 designs to this, is mindboggling! The MFI/MiG-1.42 is anything but stealthy - it might have a reduced radar cross section, but even then it's nowhere near on par with it's European competition such as the Typhoon or Rafale. Russian stealth tech is not based on the design & RAM but rather Plasma technology. If it works like they say it does, shape & size of the airplane is irrelevant. Despite the apparent technical difficulty of designing a plasma stealth device for combat aircraft, there are claims that a system was offered for export by Russia in 1999. In January 1999, the Russian ITAR-TASS news agency published an interview with Doctor Anatoliy Koroteyev, the director of the Keldysh Research Center (FKA Scientific Research Institute for Thermal Processes), who talked about the plasma stealth device developed by his organization. The claim was particularly interesting in light of the solid scientific reputation of Dr. Koroteyev and the Institute for Thermal Processes, which is one of the top scientific research organizations in the world in the field of fundamental physics. [see "Russian scientists created revolutionary technologies for reducing radar visibility of aircraft", by Nikolay Novichkov, ITAR-TASS, January 20, 1999]. The Journal of Electronic Defense reported that "plasma-cloud-generation technology for stealth applications" developed in Russia reduces an aircraft's RCS by a factor of 100. According to this June 2002 article, the Russian plasma stealth device has been tested aboard a Sukhoi Su-27IB fighter-bomber. The Journal also reported that similar research into applications of plasma for RCS reduction is being carried out by Accurate Automation Corporation (Chattanooga, Tennessee) and Old Dominion University (Norfolk, Virginia) in the U.S.; and by Dassault Aviation (Saint-Cloud, France) and Thales (Paris, France). ["Russia Working on Stealth Plasma", by Michal Fiszer and Jerzy Gruszczynski, Journal of Electronic Defense, June 2002]. +http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plasma_stealth +http://www.military-heat.com/43/russian-plasma-stealth-fighters/

Couple of prototypes were built, but officially none are in service…….. +http://www.fas.org/man/dod-101/sys/ac/row/mfi.htm BTW; IMHO one of the ugliest aircraft Russians have ever built! How they went from the Mig-29 & Su-27 designs to this, is mindboggling! The MFI/MiG-1.42 is anything but stealthy - it might have a reduced radar cross section, but even then it's nowhere near on par with it's European competition such as the Typhoon or Rafale.
reply: Russian stealth tech is not based on the design & RAM but rather Plasma technology. If it works like they say it does, shape & size of the airplane is irrelevant. Despite the apparent technical difficulty of designing a plasma stealth device for combat aircraft, there are claims that a system was offered for export by Russia in 1999. In January 1999, the Russian ITAR-TASS news agency published an interview with Doctor Anatoliy Koroteyev, the director of the Keldysh Research Center (FKA Scientific Research Institute for Thermal Processes), who talked about the plasma stealth device developed by his organization. The claim was particularly interesting in light of the solid scientific reputation of Dr. Koroteyev and the Institute for Thermal Processes, which is one of the top scientific research organizations in the world in the field of fundamental physics. [see "Russian scientists created revolutionary technologies for reducing radar visibility of aircraft", by Nikolay Novichkov, ITAR-TASS, January 20, 1999]. The Journal of Electronic Defense reported that "plasma-cloud-generation technology for stealth applications" developed in Russia reduces an aircraft's RCS by a factor of 100. According to this June 2002 article, the Russian plasma stealth device has been tested aboard a Sukhoi Su-27IB fighter-bomber. The Journal also reported that similar research into applications of plasma for RCS reduction is being carried out by Accurate Automation Corporation (Chattanooga, Tennessee) and Old Dominion University (Norfolk, Virginia) in the U.S.; and by Dassault Aviation (Saint-Cloud, France) and Thales (Paris, France). ["Russia Working on Stealth Plasma", by Michal Fiszer and Jerzy Gruszczynski, Journal of Electronic Defense, June 2002]. +http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plasma_stealth +http://www.military-heat.com/43/russian-plasma-stealth-fighters/

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: The closest I've seen to what might be a stealthy Russian fighter is the Su-47 Berkut. I don't see that as being any more stealthy than an F-15. Don Looks like something COBRA would have used on the GI Joe cartoon.
quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: The closest I've seen to what might be a stealthy Russian fighter is the Su-47 Berkut. I don't see that as being any more stealthy than an F-15. Don

title: Canadian F18 fighters intercepted Russian bombers over Arctic on eve of Obama visit

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Man....It's only a matter if time before WW III breaks loose. I will go if called and I will even volunteer if need be. Don't think you'd want to be fighting in the Arctic, or even northern Canada, Cracker. It's cold, wet, buggy and there's nowhere to go and nothing to do - except chase geese. It ain't like 'Ice Station Zebra'.

title: Canadian F18 fighters intercepted Russian bombers over Arctic on eve of Obama visit

content: quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: quote: Originally posted by FlankerFlyer: Again, a non-news story. This was a coincidence as the Russians wouldn't give a fat rat's a$$ about Obama's visit nor would they be worried about some vintage F-18s flying with 3 tanks onboard each to even make that far of intercept of an ancient pair of bombers that could have unloaded all their cruise missiles before the F-18s ever made it into missile range. If Russia would have had serious intentions they would have sent stealth aircraft that would remain undetected until its too late. Russia sent 2 bombers deep into Canadian airspace in 2006 without being detected which still has the canuks scratching their heads. Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Without hard evidence, it all sounds like a bunch of hot air, and having seen how Putin acts on the world stage, if Russia had an actual stealth aircraft, Putin's pride wouldn't have let him keep it secret - the thing would have been the pride and joy of the MAKS airshow for the world to see. The two aircraft the Russians used were probably Tu-160's. Wiki reports that the "Bears" tracked in this incident were actually Blackjacks. Two of which penetrated US air space undetected last year, causing an investigation. The Russians have re-started the Blackjack program to pad out their fleet. If it is true that CF-18's caught them over the ocean either they're not as radar deflective or fast as the Russians think. Or maybe they were on their way home.
quote: Originally posted by PhoenixDark: quote: Originally posted by FlankerFlyer: Again, a non-news story. If Russia would have had serious intentions they would have sent stealth aircraft that would remain undetected until its too late. Russia sent 2 bombers deep into Canadian airspace in 2006 without being detected which still has the canuks scratching their heads. Aside from a few YouTube posts which have about 1/1000th the credibility of a National Enquirer article, I have seen no semi-credible evidence of a Russian stealth aircraft. Without hard evidence, it all sounds like a bunch of hot air, and having seen how Putin acts on the world stage, if Russia had an actual stealth aircraft, Putin's pride wouldn't have let him keep it secret - the thing would have been the pride and joy of the MAKS airshow for the world to see.

Two of which penetrated US air space undetected last year, causing an investigation. The Russians have re-started the Blackjack program to pad out their fleet. If it is true that CF-18's caught them over the ocean either they're not as radar deflective or fast as the Russians think. Or maybe they were on their way home.
